thread.section_title: Texas High School Football & Sports | Scores & Schedules | www.statesman.com
thread.title: Roundup: Austin High snaps Hays’ three-game winning streak
thread.title_full: Roundup: Austin High snaps Hays’ three-game winning streak | www.statesman.com

author: Mike Schoeffel
title: Roundup: Austin High snaps Hays’ three-game winning streak
text:
Jacob Traudt caught 13 passes for 186 yards and three scores as Austin High snapped visiting Hays’ three-game winning streak, winning 26-17 Friday night at House Park.
Maroons quarterback Beau Kalbacher enjoyed perhaps his most efficient game of the season, throwing for 262 yards, four scores and no interceptions.
Austin High (4-2, 2-2 in District 14-6A) opened the scoring halfway through the first quarter when Kalbacher connected with Traudt for a 10-yard touchdown pass on fourth down. The Maroons came close to taking that touchdown advantage into the break, but a Kalbacher fumble gave the Rebels the ball inside the Austin 35 with two minutes to go. Five plays later, Hays’ Cody Gandy, who finished with 105 yards rushing, jogged untouched into the end zone to knot the score 7-7.
Lourdes M Shoaf Cedar Ridge’s Josh Arzola (4) pursues Pflugerville quarterback Justyn Merriweather on Friday during a District 13-6A matchup. The Raiders won 38-9 to remain unbeaten on the season. CREDIT: Lourdes M. Shoaf/ For American-Statesman.) Kalbacher atoned for his fumble at the end of the third quarter, connecting with Traudt on a 29-yard post that gave Austin High a 14-7 lead.
The fourth quarter proved to be a wild one. After Jax Kell drilled a 22-yard field goal to cut the Maroons’ lead to 14-10, Kalbacher answered with a 30-yard strike to Miles Brown to make it 20-10, but Hays didn’t fold. Quarterback Isaac Castilleja connected with Dustin Bruno for a 54-yard touchdown to slash the Rebels’ deficit to 20-17 with seven minutes to play.
Hays (4-3, 3-2) had a chance stop Austin High on a fourth down-and-6 play near midfield with two minutes to go, but Kalbacher used his legs, to accrue a 27-yard gain.
Round Rock’s Jason Uwaeze heads up the field Friday as Rouse’s Matthew Bisch gives chase. The Dragons won 60-15 and remain tied with Hendrickson and Cedar Ridge for the District 13-6A lead. CREDIT: Henry Huey/For American-Statesman Several plays later, Kalbacher sealed the victory with a 6-yard touchdown pass to his favorite target, Traudt.
Hendrickson 31, Stony Point 23: Four different Hawks found the end zone as Hendrickson (5-1, 3-0) stayed tied with Round Rock and Cedar Ridge atop the District 13-6A standings.
Hendrickson, which has won 20 of its past 22 district games, trailed 17-3 at halftime, but senior Ashton Augillard’s interception set up teammate Trent Howard’s 2-yard touchdown run, and quarterback Carrington Kearney added a 12-yard TD run after Stony Point fumbled away the ensuing kickoff. The two touchdowns, which came within 13 seconds of each other, gave the Hawks a 17-9 lead with 7:03 to go in the third quarter, and Hendrickson pushed its advantage to 31-9 before Stony Point (3-3, 0-3) rallied in the closing quarter.
— Danny Davis
Round Rock 60, Rouse 15: The Dragons (5-1, 3-0 in District 13-6A) started with a special-teams score, then unleashed their offense before finishing with some great defense to overwhelm the Raiders (2-4, 1-2) at Bible Stadium.
After James Lynch slung down Michael Forster for an eight-yard sack to set up fourth and long on Rouse’s opening drive, Albert Durden blocked the punt and Matthew James scooped up the ball from three yards out for a touchdown. Andrew Stefani’s two-point conversion run made it 8-0 just two minutes into the game.
Rouse responded with a 67-yard scoring drive, with Marquis Simmons shouldering most of the load with eight straight runs to the Round Rock 9-yard line. Forster lofted a pass to Brady Kaloustian for the TD and scored on a two-point keeper to tie the game.
After that, it was all Round Rock. Brian Bullock ran back the kickoff 80 yards to the Raiders’ 3 to set up Day’shus White with his 10th rushing touchdown of the season.
Quarterback Liam Baird counted four touchdowns among his six completions, including a pair to Zech Nash-Kelly as the Dragons took a 43-8 halftime lead.
— Bob Brinkman, AA-S correspondent
Lake Travis 60, Anderson 3: Charlie Brewer connected with Cade Brewer for a 27-yard touchdown on the game’s first play, sparking the Cavaliers (6-0, 4-0 District 14-6A) to a romp over the Trojans (2-5, 0-5) at Burger Stadium.
The Cavaliers junior quarterback finished with four touchdown passes — all in the first half — and both Abe Willows and Santiago Villegas rushed for more than 100 yards. After the opening score, Brewer hit Cade Green for two touchdowns and Maleek Barkley for another as Lake Travis cruised to a 46-0 halftime lead.
Anderson ended an 11-quarter shutout streak by the Lake Travis defense when Alfredo Estrada connected for a 30-yard field goal with 4:10 to go in the game.
Brewer finished 14-of-21 passing for 167 yards and the four scores. Willows rushed for 118 yards and two scores on just eight first-half carries. Villegas gained 143 yards on 11 carries, including a TD run.
— Jay Plotkin, AA-S correspondent
Westlake 58, Akins 19: For a quarter, the Eagles held a lead over the ninth-ranked Class 6A team in the state.
The Chaparrals (6-0, 4-0), however, scored 51 unanswered points to dismiss Akins (4-3, 2-3) in a District 14-6A game at Chaparral Stadium.
Texas Longhorns recruit Sam Ehlinger completed 15 of 20 pass attempts for 297 yards and five touchdowns for Westlake. Chase Coakley had three TD catches for the Chaparrals.
— Michael Adams, ACN
Cedar Park 51, Leander 14: Jack Grimm ran for three touchdowns as the Timberwolves, the top-ranked Class 5A team in Texas, won at Gupton Stadium.
Grimm scored on 3-, 1-, and 10-yard runs as Cedar Park (6-0, 3-0 in District 25-5A) won its eighth straight in the series with its oldest rival. Leander (2-4, 1-3) last beat Cedar Park in 2007.
Cedar Park’s defense held Leander to 216 total yards.
— Sean Shapiro, AA-S correspondent
Cedar Ridge 38, Pflugerville 9: Garrett Sharp completed 13 of 23 passes for 258 yards and four touchdowns as unbeaten Cedar Ridge remained tied for the lead in District 13-6A.
The Raiders (6-0, 3-0) scored two touchdowns in less than a minute to close out the third quarter and put the game out of reach. First, Sharp connected with Erik Wade for a 66-yard scoring pass. Then Cedar Ridge’s Jamir Williams returned an interception 46 yards for a score, pushing the Raiders’ lead to 31-9.
Pflugerville’s touchdown came in the third quarter, when Justyn Merriweather connected with Dawson Tamez for a 68-yard touchdown pass. The Panthers dropped to 1-5, 1-2.
— Butch Hart, AA-S correspondent
Reagan 27, Bastrop 15: Mulbah Car rushed for 175 yards and three touchdowns as the Raiders (3-3, 2-1 in District 26-5A) beat the Bears (3-3, 1-2) at Nelson Field.
Car was the focal point of the Raiders’ offense on a dominant 19-play, 93-yard touchdown drive that took nearly 12 minutes off the clock and ended with a 3-yard run by quarterback Amado Aguilera. The drive — all running plays — put the Raiders up 27-15 with 2:20 to go on the clock.
Reagan took an early lead when Car rushed in from one yard out to make it 6-0, but Bastrop answered with a 42-yard touchdown run from Jovahn Jones. Bastrop also got a pair of Jose Sanchez field goals from 31 and 38 yards.
Car made it a one-score game again with 5:13 to go in the half when he broke a 52-yard touchdown run. He also scored on a 10-yard run with 20 seconds to go in the half to give the Raiders a 20-15 advantage.
— Chris Dukes, ACN
Manor 57, Elgin 22: Quarterback Johnny Gaston accounted for seven touchdowns — four passing and three rushing — as the visiting Mustangs (4-3, 2-1 in District 17-5A) rolled past the Wildcats (1-6, 1-1).
Manor receiver Lyndemian Brooks had three catches for 128 yards, including a 45-yard touchdown in the third quarter.
— Travis Atkins, AA-S correspondent
Kerrville Tivy 52, Lockhart 17: In a battle of unbeaten District 27-5A teams, Kerrville Tivy totaled 493 yards in posting its its sixth consecutive win of the season. The Antlers scored on all eight of their possessions in the game.
It took 47 seconds for Kerrville Tivy to get on the board, with Ian Ronan’s 5-yard touchdown run capping a three-play drive. The Antlers added two more touchdowns in the first quarter, with Cade Dyal finding Trahan for a 50-yard touchdown pass before Dyal’s 1-yard run gave Tivy a 21-3 lead.
Lockhart (6-1, 4-1) rallied in the second quarter, with D.J. Ellison accounting for two rushing touchdowns. Ellison finished with a game-high 184 rushing yards on 32 carries. Through seven games, he has 1,342 yards rushing and 15 touchdowns.
— Quixem Ramirez, AA-S
Dripping Springs 56, East View 21: Dripping Springs scored on its first five possessions and coasted past host East View in a District 25-5A contest.
Robert Credeur led a balanced Dripping Springs rushing attack as he gained 97 yards on eight carries, which included a pair of 14-yard scoring runs. He also scored on an 18-yard pass from Reese Johnson.
The Tigers’ Collin Berzsenyi finished 5-of-7 passing for 107 yards, including a pair of scoring tosses: one to Nick Bever that covered 81 yards and a 9-yarder to Jack Bradley.
Ethan Fernea returned an interception 70 yards for a score, and he also returned the second-half kickoff 90 yards for a TD as Dripping Springs improved to 4-2 overall, 2-1 in district play.
East View (3-3, 0-3) was paced by quarterback Austin Moreno, who completed 16 of 26 passes for 255 yards, including a 51-yard scoring pass to Michael Distad.
— Mark Champ, AA-S correspondent
Cedar Creek 23, Lanier 7: Cedar Creek reached three victories for the first time since beginning varsity play in 2012. Next week, the Eagles (3-3, 3-0) will face LBJ in a battle for the District 26-5A lead.
Junior quarterback Tristan Hendrix led the way for Cedar Creek, passing for 125 yards and rushing for 81. Peyton Tuggle caught two touchdown passes from Hendrix.
Lanier (3-3, 0-3) scored on a 46-yard strike from Josh Torres to Tajik Bartholomew midway through the second quarter.
— Ken Whalen, AA-S correspondent
Waco 35, Hutto 28: Quarterback Jalen Harris fired a 33-yard touchdown strike to Julius Kennedy with 29 seconds to go to lift Waco High (4-3, 2-1 District 17-5A) to a victory.
Visiting Hutto (4-2, 1-1) had fought back from three deficits to take the lead at 28-21 on Noah Ramos’ 2-yard run with 5:27 to play in the game. Then Harris made the first of two critical plays. After the kickoff, he ran 75 yards for a score with 5:10 to go to make it 28-all.
Hutto’s Tyler Herrick completed 25 of 39 passes for 274 yards with one TD and no interceptions.
Georgetown 45, Marble Falls 7: Chandler Herman passed for three touchdowns and ran for two more as the Eagles (4-2, 1-2) picked up their first District 25-5A victory.
A Marble Falls fumble set up Herman for a 3-yard TD run to open the scoring with 4:46 left in the first quarter. Herman hit Beau Corrales for a 33-yard touchdown with 41 seconds to play in the period.
Jo’Vonta Grimble pulled down a Herman pass in the corner of the end zone for a 21-0 halftime advantage.
Marble Falls (1-4, 0-2) scored on a 22-play drive that covered 86 yards and ended with Robert Atkinson’s 1-yard run.
Liberty Hill 31, Canyon Lake 7: Dyllon Joiner returned a fumble 55 yards for a touchdown — one of four turnovers Liberty Hill’s defense produced — and the visiting Panthers (4-2) opened District 14-4A, Division I play with a victory.
Jon Shannon ran for 125 yards on 24 carries for Liberty Hill. He started the scoring with a 30-yard run in the second quarter. Then Joiner notched the defensive score for a 14-0 lead.
China Spring 42, Burnet 20: The unbeaten Cougars (5-0, 1-0) displayed a dominant ground game to win the District 13-4A, Division I contest.
Brock Foster had a 19-yard run to give the Bulldogs (4-2, 0-1) an early lead. Burnet trailed 21-13 at the half before China Springs took command with a 14-0 third quarter. Bulldogs quarterback Austin Moore completed 27 of 40 passes for 225 yards, with two touchdowns and one interception.
Lago Vista 25, Florence 21: Quarterback Austin Polk passed for three touchdowns and ran for two to guide the host Vikings (2-4, 1-0 in District 10-3A, Division I) past the Buffaloes (4-2, 0-1).
Polk’s 62-yard TD pass to running back Jacob Carpeno gave Lago Vista a 28-6 lead late in the third quarter. It was Carpeno’s only catch. He also had 61 yards rushing.
Edel Hernandez ran for 196 yards and two scores for Florence.
La Grange 51, Smithville 13: La Grange (6-1) scored 42 unanswered points to win its District 11-4A, Division II opener.
Visiting Smithville (1-6, 0-1) took a 13-9 on the first play of the second quarter, when Garrett Mathis hit Cade Goertz with a 9-yard touchdown pass. The lead was short-lived, however, as La Grange junior JK Dobbins scored the first of his four touchdowns on a 33-yard scamper. Dobbins scored again in the second quarter, this time on an 86-yard run, to boost the Leopards’ lead to 23-13.
Dobbins finished with 342 yards on 22 carries.
— Robbie Brown, AA-S correspondent
Hyde Park 25, Regents 24: Seth Devries scored on a run and a reception in the fourth quarter to give the host Panthers (5-0, 1-0) a one-point victory over the Knights (2-4, 1-1).
Devries ran 32 yards for a touchdown to bring Hyde Park within 24-19. Then he caught a 5-yard pass from Bo Stewart for the game winner in the TAPPS contest. It was his only reception. Devries rushed 26 times for 169 yards.
